Hi Peter,

I cannot add more to what Ken said, this is an entirely new fiel=
d and 
a cutting edge of research but I suggest you take a look at my NEVH =

project as well (it is located in the files section in this group). 
It is=
 written in C++ and utilizes HyperNEAT for constructing the 
phenotypes. It=
 also uses leaky integrators for the phenotype neuron 
model. The outputs t=
here are not joint torques, but the desired angle 
of the joint.
It might b=
e helpful to you, since we are both trying to achieve the 
same thing actua=
lly :)
By the way I want to ask you if we could join forces to collaborate =

on such a project because it is a very interesting thing and I have 
some =
experience with it. You can contact me in Skype (spookey85) if 
you agree. =


Peter Chervenski

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "peterberrington" <peterbe=
rrington@...> 
wrote:
>
> Thanks for your quick response Ken!
> You've give=
n me a lot to think about, I just have to ponder the
> specifics of how to =
compare behaviours in an objective way in this 
domain.
> 
> Heres a linux =
only version that I was working on recently, its 
really
> messy and I'm su=
re my code can use a LOT of improvement (I was kind 
of
> learning as I wen=
t along). I only wrote the toribash-esque 
experiment
> and a few changes a=
nd features added to python-neat. The actual
> python-neat backend is writt=
en by Cesar Gomez and is really 
terrific,
> as python has a certain elegan=
ce about it that makes it seem easier 
to
> grasp. 
> 
> In order to get it=
 to work you need to download the linux version of
> Command Line Breve:
> =
http://www.spiderland.org/download.php
> Then unzip this in the breve_2.7.2=
/ directory:
> http://peter.berrington.googlepages.com/tori.7z
> 
> To evol=
ve, open a shell and navigate to the breve directory, then 
call
> the Tori=
Exp with python, like this:
> python tori/toriExp.py
> To view the last bes=
t individual, instead type this:
> ./bin/breve tori/viewlastbest.py
> 
> Th=
eres a HUGE amount of parameters for which I have no idea what the
> good v=
alues are. The creator of Toribash is giving me a description 
of
> how his=
 game works but is not at all forthcoming with the specific
> implementatio=
n details; I suppose he is reluctant to give away code
> for something he m=
akes money on, but it's frustrating as his game is
> actually very well bal=
anced, allowing some very nimble and natural
> looking acrobatics. Trial an=
d error is probably the only solution at
> this stage.
> 
> I encourage peo=
ple to fool around with this; I'm a complete beginner
> to programming this=
 kind of stuff and I've got a lot of really
> terrible code I'm sure, so pl=
ease submit any changes that you think
> would make sense.
> 
> 
> --- In n=
eat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> >
> > Hi Peter,=
 that's a good question and of course learning to 
control a 
> > virtual c=
reature with novelty search is a complicated issue (and 
an 
> > appealing =
idea as well). 
> > 
> > First, you have to deal with all the representatio=
nal and 
physical 
> > issues outside of novelty search, like how many inpu=
ts, how many 
> > outputs, and whether the body itself is not physically fl=
awed in 
> > some way (which is possible).  As you are experiencing, the 
>=
 > inputs/outputs issue can be prohibitive even with feature 
> > selection=
.  It is also possible that HyperNEAT could be useful 
> > because it does =
not care about the # inputs or outputs (and can 
> > potentially exploit ge=
ometric regularities), but configuring the 
> > substrate then becomes the =
challenge.
> > 
> > Assuming all of that stuff is set up well with whatever=
 system, 
then 
> > novelty search is a potentially winning approach.  Yet =
as you 
point 
> > out there are some big questions there as well.  In fact=
, we are 
> > currently trying to provide the best answers to these questio=
ns 
in 
> > ongoing research, but some general principles might help for no=
w: 
> > 
> > First, the archive in novelty search does not not need to cont=
ain 
> > every point ever visited.  Therefore, it tends to grow much 
slowe=
r 
> > than the #of evaluations.  However, if it is indeed getting too 
big=
  
> > then it is not unreasonable to collapse some of the archive 
points,=
 
> > although there is no standard method yet for how that should be 
> > =
done.  But we have reason to believe there will be effective and 
> > simpl=
e ways to do that.
> > 
> > Second, the issue of one individual looking dif=
ferent just 
because 
> > of a phase difference in effectivley the same beh=
avior is 
> > complicated.  For certain phase disaparities, the two individ=
uals 
> > won't look all that different, but it is true that at some 
> > d=
isparity, they may look very different.  Yet it is not clear 
> > whether t=
hat fact is actually problematic to the novelty search 
or 
> > not, becaus=
e it would simply reward both types of behavior.  It 
is 
> > possible that=
 the phase difference is a result of some useful 
> > genotypic change, whi=
ch could make it a stepping stone to 
something 
> > better.  Or, it is pos=
sible that it is superfluous information 
and 
> > simply takes some extra =
time exploring the area around the phase-
> > shifted individual.  So it is=
 hard to say a priori whether it is 
a 
> > major concern.  We will have be=
tter answers to such questions as 
the 
> > technique is further explored.
=
> > 
> > However, I agree that it would be nice to be able to say the two 
=
> > phase-shifted individuals are largely the same if that is indeed 
> > w=
hat you want to say.  And for that, you would need a pattern-
> > matching =
metric to compute behavioral distance, i.e. something 
more 
> > sophisitic=
ated than simple Cartesian distance.  There are 
certainly 
> > such metric=
s available.  However, it's important to recognize 
that 
> > it is not evi=
dent at this point that ignoring the phase shift is 
> > actually better th=
an taking it into consideration, because taking 
it 
> > into consideration=
 just means adding more information to the 
novelty 
> > landscape.
> > 
> =
> So overall I think novelty search is a very promising direction 
to 
> > =
go for such problems, but it is still in the realm of research 
(i.e. 
> > =
there is no existing precedent), so it will involve considerable 
> > trial=
 and error to get it right until all these issues are 
fleshed 
> > out mor=
e clearly.  Ultimately, though, if our hypothesis about 
> > novelty vs. fi=
tness is correct, novelty search may turn out to be 
> > the *only* way to =
get certain highly complex types of behavior to 
> > evolve in some domains=
, which is a sobering thought.  But if it 
is 
> > true, then there is not =
much to do other than try it.
> > 
> > ken
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups=
.com, "peterberrington" <peterberrington@> 
> > wrote:
> > >
> > > I've rea=
d Ken's latest paper on novelty search and its a 
> > fascinating
> > > new=
 approach. For the past couple of months I've been working on
> > > virtual=
 creature controllers; specifically I have a ragdoll rig 
> > which
> > > I=
've set up in Breve Simulation Environment (available at
> > > http://spide=
rland.org )
> > > This ragdoll is modelled after the one in Toribash, a fre=
e game 
> > which
> > > uses the open dynamics engine for physics, like bre=
ve. 
> > > 
> > > So far a lot of the results I've been having discouraging=
; as 
Ken
> > > points out early on in his latest paper, trying to make a 
=
walking
> > > biped usually results in it falling over perpetually. You can=
 
see 
> > some
> > > WIP videos at my youtube page here:
> > > http://www.=
youtube.com/user/thehaircrow
> > > 
> > > Ultimately, I would like to packa=
ge AI's with the Toribash game 
so
> > > that they are fun to play against =
in single player- I think 
this 
> > goal
> > > is attainable despite being=
 difficult.
> > > Deception is a BIG problem here; if my fitness criteria i=
s time
> > > integrated distance from a goal, it encourages the behaviour o=
f 
the
> > > "Tori" balancing in a stable configuration forever, rather tha=
n
> > > walking, which is what I'm trying to encourage. As there is 20 
> >=
 joints
> > > in this rig, I am providing joint position and velocity 
info=
rmation
> > > for each joint, as well as a bias, a sine-wave, the x, y, and=
 z
> > > components linear velocity in the reference frame of the Tori's 
>=
 > head,
> > > and finally 3 variables which correspond to the vertical, 
>=
 > horizontal
> > > and forward orientation of the tori's head with respect=
 to world
> > > coordinates.  
> > > The current experimental configuration=
 I am started out as 
a "pure"
> > > ragdoll control where neural net outpu=
ts correspond directly 
joint
> > > velocity; a tanh activation function is=
 used to allow positive 
and
> > > negative joint movement.
> > > I then re=
modeled the experiment to perform as in the Toribash 
game;
> > > the net w=
ill receive inputs (and effect joint movements) only 
> > every 10
> > > ti=
me steps. More importantly, I increased the amount of outputs 
> > from
> >=
 > 20 (1 per joint) to 40, in order to accomodate the 4 possible 
joint
> >=
 > actions which can occur on a turn: holding, relaxing, 
extending, 
> > a=
nd
> > > flexing. 
> > > 
> > > Starting with a fully connected net, that g=
ives a staggeringly 
huge
> > > search space with over 1000 connections. Du=
e to the 
implementation,
> > > its prohibitively slow to evolve large nets=
 as the starting net 
can
> > > take up over 600mb of ram on the heap. Real=
izing this was a bit
> > > ridiculous, I implemented feature selection and =
phased pruning.
> > > However, even with this, deception seems to prevent a=
ny useful
> > > behaviour; the Tori will always get stuck in ruts.
> > > 
>=
 > > 
> > > I am using a python implementation of neat developed by Cesar 
=
Gomez
> > > under the GPL, which is available at 
http://code.google.com/p/=
neat-
> > python/
> > > 
> > > This implementation is a WIP and I've alread=
y done a lot of 
tests
> > > trying to incorporate the linear genome encodi=
ng taken from the 
> > EANT
> > > method. I've also been trying to incorpor=
ate CMA-ES in order to
> > > optimize weights but I haven't had much succes=
s meshing this 
with 
> > the
> > > rest of the code yet.
> > > 
> > > Late=
r today when I am home I will post my source files for 
anyone 
> > who
> >=
 > wishes to experiment with virtual creature neuroevolution.
> > > 
> > > =

> > > 
> > > FINALLY, my question. The behaviour of a Tori is currently 
>=
 > represented
> > > as a list of 20 base 4 variables multiplied by the amo=
unt of 
time
> > > steps the Tori is evaluated for. The novelty search meth=
od 
proposed
> > > for the 2d maze navigation is fairly simple; if theres a=
 new 
ending
> > > point then 
> > > we add that point to a list of discove=
red behaviours. This 
works 
> > well
> > > (I imagine) because a point isn=
't a lot of information to hold.
> > > 
> > > What I want to know is how I =
can compare the behaviour of 2 
ragdoll
> > > controllers for novelty; is t=
here any compact encoding that 
would
> > > work? Since it often takes 25 0=
00 seperate evaluations to get 
any
> > > useful behaviour out of this righ=
t now, theres going to have to 
be
> > > some way to store 20k seperate beh=
aviours in some way that is 
fast 
> > and
> > > easy to compare; what if a=
 Tori has identical behaviour to 
another 
> > but
> > > does things a coup=
le of time steps later instead? Just 
comparing 
> > the
> > > two behaviou=
rs it would appear that they were 100% unique, yet 
a 
> > human
> > > obse=
rver would instantly notice the similarity in how they act.
> > > 
> > > An=
y ideas?
> > >
> >
>
